Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation2: A journal submission deadline is imminent and requires the finalized report and datasets.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the research report half-finished and datasets still needing to be double-checked. The journal’s submission portal was open in another tab, the countdown to the deadline ticking away. My phone buzzed with a message from my stepbrother: “Don’t forget, dinner’s at 7. Mom really wants us all together tonight.” I could almost hear the expectation in his words—after all, I was still the “new” sibling, and these dinners were supposed to help us bond. But the thought of leaving my work unfinished, risking errors in my data or missing the deadline, made my stomach twist. My lab supervisor had reminded me just this morning: “Accuracy and timeliness are everything in science.” I felt pulled in two directions—one toward the warmth and acceptance of my new family, the other toward the cold, exacting standards of my profession. My hands hovered over the keyboard, heart pounding, as I tried to decide which world needed me more tonight.
